required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ultrasound Crestal Bone Topography of Edentulous Ridges
clinical_study.official_title: Evaluation of Crestal Bone Topography of Edentulous Ridges: A Retrospective Study Comparing Ultrasonography to Cone-Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT)

brief_summary.textblock: A successful implant surgery primarily relies on a prudent evaluation of oral anatomy and meticulous treatment planning. Additionally, of paramount importance that dictates the types of procedures, material selection and ultimately success of implant surgery is the quality and quantity of the edentulous ridge. Ultrasound imaging (US), another cross-sectional imaging modality, has been extensively used in the medical diagnostics field. The ability of ultrasound to image soft tissue-bone interface makes it particularly promising for studying bone ridge width and crestal bone topography. Therefore, this retrospective human study aimed to compare bone width measurements between US and CBCT. This study also investigated the possible correlation between the crestal bone surface quality imaged by US and CBCT.

primary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of ultrasound for estimating ridge width
primary_outcome.time_frame: up to 3 months after image was taken
primary_outcome.description: measure the edentulous ridge width at 1, 2 and 3 mm apical to the crest on ultrasound images

secondary_outcome.measure: Accuracy of ultrasound for assessing ridge surface quality
secondary_outcome.time_frame: up to 3 months after image was taken
secondary_outcome.description: Evaluate the crestal bone surface quality with ultrasound

arm_group.description: This group had edentulous ridge planning to receive a dental implant and had ultrasound and cone-beam computed tomography images of the ridge.

study_pop.textblock: Records of patients who had at least 1 edentulous ridge with a plan for implant placement, had cone-beam computed tomography as standard procedure and ultrasound imaging for off-label use of evaluating the ridge were included.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patient records at the Graduate Periodontal Clinic
- With both US and CBCT scans taking within 3 months between each other from Jan 2016 to Mar 2020
- These images had to include at least one edentulous ridge at the anterior, premolar or molar site.
- Multiple sites in a given patient may be included.

facility.name: University of Michigan School of Dentistry
